results.title: Hook
results.creator_credit: Tri-Star Pictures, Kathleen Kennedy, Frank Marshall, Gerald Molen and Steven Spielberg
results.brief_description: Steven Spielberg filters J.M. Barrie’s ‘Peter Pan’ through a distinctly 90’s sensibility in ‘Hook’, a film of lost opportunities. Peter Pan has become Peter Banning (Robin Williams), a 40 year old lawyer with a permanent scowl on his face. Banning has lost all memory of being Peter Pan, and he is also in danger of losing his wife and children. When Peter and his family travel to London to visit Granny Wendy, Peter’s children are kidnapped by Captain Hook. As Peter recalls who he is and re-discovers his happy thoughts, he transforms into the Peter Pan of the past and goes to rescue his children. Cast includes Dustin Hoffman, Julia Roberts, Bob Hoskins and Maggie Smith.

results.title: Honeymoon in Vegas (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Castle Rock Entertainment, New Line Cinema, Mike Lobell and Andrew Bergman
results.brief_description: Nicholas Cage is Jack Singer, a second-rate private eye who has somehow managed to win the undying love of gorgeous school teacher, Betsy Nolan (Sarah Jessica Parker). Now, after 5 years Betsy wants a commitment, but Jack is plagued by his mother’s deathbed wish that he never marry. In an irrational moment Jack relents and they travel to Vegas to exchange their vows, and this is where the trouble begins. Featuring James Caan as a wealthy, evil card-shark and a cast including several-hundred Elvis impersonators, it’s a hunka hunka burnin’ fun!
results.creator_credit_for_label: Castle Rock Entertainment, New Line Cinema, Mike Lobell and Andrew Bergman

results.title: Hondo
results.creator_credit: Wayne-Fellows Productions, Robert Fellows and John Farrow
results.brief_description: Based on the novel by Louis L’Amour, John Wayne’s own favourite movie features the actor in the role of Hondo, a half-Indian cavalry scout. Set in 1874 against the unrest and hostility caused by the white man’s violation of the treaty with the Apache Nation, the plot concerns Hondo’s protection of a young woman and her son whom he discovers living alone in Apache territory. The film extends liberal respect to the Indians and even implicitly endorses the inter-racial romance that develops between the white women and the half-breed Hondo. With impressive cinematography by Robert Burke, the film was restored and re-released by the John Wayne estate in 1995. Cast includes Geraldine Page. Ward Bond and Michael Pate.

results.title: Home alone (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, John Hughes and Chris Columbus
results.brief_description: This is one of the most successful comedies of the eighties and stars pint-sized hero Macaulay Culkin. In a chaotic frenzy to get to the airport on time, the McCallister family forget one thing - eight year old Kevin. When two bungling burglars attempt to break into the McCallister household, Kevin is left home alone to defend himself and his house. He outwits the burglars by waging war the only way he knows how. A John Hughes film co-starring Joe Pesci, “Home alone” is a modern-day classic.

results.title: Hombre
results.creator_credit: Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, Martin Ritt and Irving Ravetch
results.brief_description: Paul Newman is the hero in this exciting, hard hitting western. John Russell is a white man raised as an Apache who faces the prejudices of a society which despises him. He is made to sit outside the stage coach by the white passengers who soon find that their lives are dependent on the man they rejected when outlaws leave them stranded in the desert. Co-starring Diane Cilento, Frederic March, Richard Boone and Barbara Rush.

results.title: Holy smoke
results.creator_credit: Miramax Films, Saddleback Productions, Jan Chapman and Jane Campion
results.brief_description: During a backpacking holiday in India, Ruth, a young Australian woman, experiences a spiritual awakening at an ashram. Convinced that she has found peace, harmony and purpose she decides to stay on with her newfound guru, much to the horror of her family in Australia. Luring her back to suburban Sydney on false pretences they employ the services of P.J., an American ‘cult-exiter’. The deprogramming encounter that takes place over three days in a shack on an isolated outback farm becomes a battle of wits and wills over spirituality and sexuality. Returning to the themes of dysfunctional family life that she focused on in her first feature “Sweetie”, Campion employs cultural stereotypes to contrast the exotic appeal of Eastern spiritualism for the idealistic Ruth, with her family’s lack of understanding and crassness. The film’s central concern with the search for the meaning of life is juxtaposed with comedic elements drawn from the repertoire of cliched Australian ‘types’ that were a commonplace of Australian cinema in the nineties, and moments of high melodrama. Though Campion clearly demonstrated her cinematic and technical proficiency, the narrative was considered by some critics to be somewhat clumsy and overambitious.

results.title: Holy man
results.creator_credit: Touchstone Pictures, Roger Birnbaum and Stephen Herek
results.brief_description: An examination and re-evaluation of morals and ethics drives this comedy/drama about a television executive and a marketing manager who despite loathing each other, must work together. The two identify their misguided paths assisted by an enigmatic character named ‘G’, who seems to possess miraculous powers. Stars Eddie Murphy (as G), Jeff Goldblum and Kelly Preston.

results.title: Hollywood or bust
results.creator_credit: Paramount Pictures, Hal Wallis and Frank Tashlin
results.brief_description: Hollywood or bust marked the last collaboration between Jerry Lewis and Dean Martin and the second time the pair were directed by Frank Tashlin (who directed numerous Jerry Lewis comedies). When Steve Wiley (Dean Martin) rigs a car raffle in order to pay off the bookies that he is deeply indebted to, he also lands a partnership with Malcolm Smith (Jerry Lewis), the real winner of the prize. With a new car, Malcolm decides to head to Hollywood in order to meet the starlet he is besotted with, Anita Ekberg (playing herself); Steve decides to join him and hopefully win some dough in the Las Vegas casinos to pay the henchmen after him. The two head cross-country with Malcolm’s great dane in tow; they also lend a ride to Terry (Pat Crowley), a pretty singer for whom Wiley falls. This musical comedy and road movie contains much of the usual slapstick that was Lewis’ signature schtick; it also plays up to Martin’s image as the smooth and charming lady-killer. Reportedly the shoot was not a fun one with Lewis being a difficult and rambunctious presence on set.

results.title: Hollow man
results.creator_credit: Columbia Pictures, Douglas Wick, Alan Marshall and Paul Verhoeven
results.brief_description: Scientist Sebastian Caine (Kevin Bacon) and his team have spent years trying to discover the formula to make matter invisible. When initial testing on a gorilla proves the developed serum works, Caine is pressured into testing it on a human candidate by his supervisor Dr. Kramer (William Devane), despite the formula being unstable. Rather than screen likely candidates, Caine decides to test the serum on himself. However, while the formula injected into the gorilla could be reversed, once Caine proves that his formula also works on humans his team are unable to reverse the process. Despite the team’s efforts to find a solution, Caine, unable to deal with his invisibility goes insane and begins to stalk his research team, in particular his ex-girlfriend Linda (Elisabeth Shue) and Matt (Josh Brolin), her new boyfriend. Director Paul Verhoeven uses computer-aided special effects in an amazingly realistic portrayal of invisibility in this sci-fi thriller which also stars Kim Dickens, Mary Jo Randle and Joey Slotnick.

results.title: Holiday
results.creator_credit: Columbia Pictures, Everett Riskin and George Cukor
results.brief_description: Adapted from Philip Barry’s play and a remake of a film made in 1930, George Cukor’s “Holiday” is a wonderful comedy which subtly examines the lives of an unhappy wealth family and a carefree young man who enters their plush world. When Johnny Case (Cary Grant) returns from a skiing holiday to visit his fiance Julie Seton (Doris Nolan) he is shocked to discover she is very very rich. Soon Julie’s father is mapping out their lives, but Julie’s non-conformist sister Linda (Katherine Hepburn) and alcholic brother Ned (Lew Ayres) think that Johnny’s fresh enthusiasm for life could be the antidote for their father’s tiranic rule. Hepburn and Grant give fantastic performances and Cukor’s direction ensures that this is a sparkling romantic comedy.
